com.reactivecascade.i

Interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IAsyncOrigin, ICancellable, IGettable<OUT>, ISafeGettable<OUT>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    IRunnableAltFuture<IN,OUT>, ISettableAltFuture<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractAltFuture, AbstractAltFuture.OnCancelledAltFuture, CompoundAltFuture, OnCancelledAltFuture, OnErrorAltFuture, RunnableAltFuture, SettableAltFuture

    public interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
extends ICancellable, ISafeGettable<OUT>, IAsyncOrigin
    One of many possible futures in the multiverse. Future. A Future that follows an alternative contract split supports a slightly different set of methods split exception handling.

    A traditional Future @see Java Future is blocking when referencing the from. It turns out others have been trying to very similarly work past the limitations of Future by executing a callback on completion, notably Java 8 with CompletableFuture @see Java 8 CompletableFuture, the Guava library's ListenableFuture @see Guava ListenableFuture, and Scala's implementation of Future @see Scala Future. All three of these solutions are suitable for server development. Guava configured with appropriate Proguard minimization is suitable for Android.

    RunnableAltFuture differs from the above alternatives by providing an execution model and strictly defined inter-thread communication and error handling contract. You may want think of this as aspect-oriented programming with each RunnableAltFuture in a functional chain strictly associated with an IThreadType. The defined thread type (a named group of one or more threads) explicitly sets the maximum concurrency contract. The ideal concurrency for a given step in a functional chain is determined by the primary limiting resource of that purely functional computational step or side effect. This can be determined and fixed at the time the IAltFuture is defined. The limiting resource may be the necessity for a piece of code to execute synchronously after other UI code on the application's main thread. If this is not required, then the number of CPU cores on the execution device or other primary resource constraint such to that thread type such as the optimal number of concurrent network write operations for current network conditions. Used properly, this should lead to work throughput increases, reduced work in progress, latency reduction, and peak memory use bounding while keeping the code simple and highly productive.

    Non-cooperative interrupts and blocking actions like Future.get(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit) are not allowed in this model. These are replaced with an explicit dependency .then() action chain with simple asynchronous exception handling.

    Instead, use IGettable.get(). If the IAltFuture has not yet completed execution successfully it will immediately throw a IllegalStateException at run time. This allows you to make your lambdas more simple, but still handle asynchronous by functional chaining.

    IAltFuture requires a more strict contract than Future. While a Future allows you to "merge" (wait for) a task which has not yet completed, IAltFuture requires execution to the point of returning such a prerequisite from to complete before the request to IGettable.get() is made. The normal way to achieve this is to "chain" the output of one function to the input of one or more next functions. For example map(IActionOneR) will create an RunnableAltFuture which will receive as input the output of this, process it split output another from in turn.

    IAltFuture implementations are compatible with Future. The default implementation RunnableAltFuture is not a Future to avoid confusion.

      static String CHECK_RESULT_SUGGESTION

    • Field Detail

      • CHECK_RESULT_SUGGESTION

        static final String CHECK_RESULT_SUGGESTION
        A method which returns a new (unforked) IAltFuture should follow the naming conventiond ..Async and be annotated @CheckResult(suggest = IAltFuture.CHECK_RESULT_SUGGESTION) to CheckResult that it is either stored or manually fork()ed.

        TODO This annotation is not ideal for disambiguating all cases, look at creating a new one

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getThreadType

        @NonNull
IThreadType getThreadType()
        Find which thread pool and related support functions are used
        Returns:
        thread group

      • isDone

        boolean isDone()
        Find if the final, immutable state has been entered either with a successful result or an error code
        Returns:
        true once final state has been determined

      • isForked

        boolean isForked()
        Find if this object has already been submitted to an executor. Execution may finish at any time, or already have finished if this is true.
        Returns:
        true once queued for execution

      • fork

        @NonNull
IAltFuture<IN,OUT> fork()
        Place this IAltFuture in the ready-to-run-without-blocking queue of its IThreadType. If there is a getUpchain() subscribe that will be forked instead until finding one where isDone() is false.
        Returns:
        this, which is usually the IAltFuture which was actually forked. The fork may be indirect and only after other items complete because there is a search upchain (which may be a different branch spliced into the current chain) to find the first unforked from.

      • getUpchain

        @Nullable
IAltFuture<?,? extends IN> getUpchain()
        Find the previous step in the chain.

        Once isDone(), this may return null even if there was a previous alt future at one point. This is done to allow a chain to reduce peak load and increase memory throughput by freeing memory of previous steps as it goes.

        Returns:
        the previous IAltFuture in the chain, or null if this is currently the head of the chain

      • setUpchain

        void setUpchain(@NonNull
                IAltFuture<?,? extends IN> altFuture)
        This is done for you when you add functions to a chain. You do not need to call it yourself.

        The implementation may call this multiple times to support merging chains. This happens most often when a method returns the tail of a section of chain. The returned from in this case is a new chain link stopping the merged chain section which might start burning before the merger is created to not burn past the merger point until the primary chain reaches that point also.

        Parameters:
        altFuture - the previous alt future in the chain to which this is attached

      • onError

        void onError(@NonNull
             ICancellable.StateError stateError)
      throws Exception
        Notification from an up-chain IAltFuture that the stream is broken and will not complete normally. This RunnableAltFuture will be set to an error state.

        If an mOnError or catch method has been defined, it will be notified of the original cause of the failure. If the RunnableAltFuture's mOnError method consumes the error (returns true), subscribe anything else down-chain methods will be notified with #onCancelled(StateCancelled) instead.

        Parameters:
        stateError - the state indicating the reason and origin of the exception
        Throws:
        Exception - if there is a problem performing synchronous downchain notifications

      • onCancelled

        void onCancelled(@NonNull
                 ICancellable.StateCancelled stateCancelled)
          throws Exception
        Notification indicates an up-chain IAltFuture has been cancelled. This RunnableAltFuture will be set to a cancelled state and not be given a chance to complete normally. All down-chain AltFutures will similarly be notified that they were cancelled.
        Parameters:
        stateCancelled - the state indicating the reason and origin of cancellation
        Throws:
        Exception - if there is a problem performing synchronous downchain notifications

        @NonNull
 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
IAltFuture<?,OUT> on(@NonNull
                                                                         IThreadType theadType)
        Switch following (downchain) actions to run on the specified IThreadType
        Parameters:
        theadType - the thread execution group to change to for the next chain operation
        Returns:
        the previous chain link alt future from continuing the chain on the new IThreadType

<DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> then(@NonNull

      • then

        @NonNull
 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
<DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> then(@NonNull
                                                                                                       IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> altFuture)
        Start an action wrapped as an alt futre after this alt future completes. This next alt future may be on a different IThreadType thread pool.

        Multiple altFutures may be chained after the current alt future. They will be fork()ed in the orderin which they were attached. Depending on their thread type, the resulting execution may be concurrent or serial.

        Type Parameters:
        DOWNCHAIN_OUT - the type that the OUT value will be mapped to. This may not be a mapping alt future, in which case the type DOWNCHAIN_OUT = OUT and the value is also identical
        Parameters:
        altFuture - the next action in the chain
        Returns:
        altFuture

      • map

        @NonNull
 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
<DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> map(@NonNull
                                                                                                      IActionOneR<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> action)
        Execute the mOnFireAction after this RunnableAltFuture finishes.
        Type Parameters:
        DOWNCHAIN_OUT - the type that the OUT value will be mapped to
        Parameters:
        action - function to be performed, often a lambda statement
        Returns:
        an alt future value representing the eventual output from the mapping function

      • map

 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
<DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT>[] map(@NonNull
                                                                                                        IActionOneR<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT>... actions)

      • sleep

        @NonNull
 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
ISettableAltFuture<OUT> sleep(long sleepTime,
                                                                                  @NonNull
                                                                                  TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Pause execution of this chain for a fixed time interval. Other chains will be able to execute in the meanwhile- no threads are blocked.

        Note that the chain realizes immediately in the event of ICancellable.cancel(String) or a runtime error

        Parameters:
        sleepTime - to pause the chain, in timeUnit values
        timeUnit - to pause
        Returns:
        the input value from upchain

      • await

        @NonNull
 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
ISettableAltFuture<OUT> await(@NonNull
                                                                                  IAltFuture<?,?>... altFutures)
        Continue chain execution once all upchain futures realize and have completed their side effects.

        The await operation will be cancelled or exception state and trigger onError(IActionOne) if any of the joined operations have a problem running to completion.

        Parameters:
        altFutures - to pause this chain until they are done (isDone())
        Returns:
        the upchain value of this chain, execution held until other alt futures complete

      • filter

        @NonNull
 @CheckResult(suggest="IAltFuture#fork()")
IAltFuture<IN,IN> filter(@NonNull
                                                                             IActionOneR<IN,Boolean> action)
        Pass through to the next function only if element meet a logic test, otherwise ICancellable.cancel(String)
        Parameters:
        action - function to be performed, often a lambda statement
        Returns:
        the input value, now guaranteed to meet the logic test

        Returns:

      • onError

        @NonNull
ISettableAltFuture<OUT> onError(@NonNull
                                         IActionOne<Exception> action)
        Add an action which will be performed if this AltFuture or any AltFuture up-chain either has a runtime error or is ICancellable.cancel(String)ed.

        This is typically a user notification or cleanup such as removing an ongoing process indicator (spinner).

        Parameters:
        action - function to be performed, often a lambda statement
        Returns:
        this

      • onCancelled

        @NonNull
ISettableAltFuture<OUT> onCancelled(@NonNull
                                             IActionOne<String> action)
        Add an action which will be performed if this AltFuture or any AltFuture up-chain either has a runtime error or is ICancellable.cancel(String)ed.

        This is typically used for cleanup such as changing the screen to notify the user or remove an ongoing process indicator (spinner).

        Parameters:
        action - function to be performed, often a lambda statement
        Returns:
        this
